image.altText: A woman takes a photo from a boat of an erupting volcano

items.synopsis: The Whakaari White Island trial hears from experts that a shipping container placed on the volcano "as a shelter" was of little value in the event of an eruption.

title.children: Shipping container was of 'little effective value' as shelter during eruption, court hears

image.altText: Blue and white tape across a road

title.children: Four injured in alleged attack by 'agitated' man in Melbourne's north-west

title.children: Fact check: Do the polls show that Indigenous support for the Voice is between 80 and 90 per cent?

title.children: Decades after their abuse ended, four women unite to jail a paedophile

items.synopsis: Donald Trump has been formally indicted for a third time, over alleged attempts to overturn the 2020 presidential election that culminated in the January 6 insurrection. Here's what we know so far.

title.children: 'The defendant knew they were false': The key takeaways from Donald Trump's third indictment

items.synopsis: Former US president Donald Trump has been indicted on four charges related to attempts to overturn the 2020 US presidential election.

title.children: Trump faces charges including conspiracy to defraud US, obstruction of official proceeding

title.children: 'Glitzy' photos of bodybuilders on stage made Angela want to join them. She didn't see the health risks

items.synopsis: South Africa has taken great pride in hosting its first major netball tournament, but World Cup organisers have stunted the event's potential with a number of failures, writes Brittany Carter.

title.children: Netball World Cup marred by ticketing issues, theft and poor organisation

image.altText: A man slam dunking a basketball.

items.synopsis: A new documentary celebrating Luc Longley's three consecutive NBA championships, and featuring exclusive new footage from The Last Dance, will offer a fascinating insight into the Australian basketball legend.

title.children: Luc Longley steps out of Michael Jordan's shadow in new NBA documentary

image.altText: Unidentified child drawing.

items.synopsis: Gaye was sexually abused when she was a young child. Warning signs at the time were ignored or brushed under the carpet and when her fragments of memories of the abuse came together years later, she found she was still being "silenced".

title.children: Five-year-old Gaye drew men differently to other kids. Her drawings held a sinister revelation

image.altText: A man in a suit on a laptop searching real estate websites.

items.synopsis: A leading economist warns the risk of further falls in house prices remains "very high", despite the Reserve Bank's decision to leave interest rates on hold for the second month in a row.

title.children: 'Very high' risk of a double-dip property downturn amid 'premature' house price rebound

image.altText: A television studio is seen through glass windows underneath an ABC News logo.

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: ABC reverses decision to scrap local 7pm Sunday news bulletins — the latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New South Wales Premier Chris Minns says his government is taking steps to look at any gaps in child protection regulations, after the shocking arrest of a childcare worker who allegedly raped and abused 91 girls over a 15 year period. The 45-year-old Gold Coast man is facing hundreds of charges over the abuse, which allegedly occured in Brisbane, Sydney and overseas between 2007 and 2022. The allegations have raised questions about the strength and suitability of background checks for people working with children. Minns has told parliament the situation is every parent's worst nightmare and he's determined to make sure there is better information sharing between jurisdictions.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Shock child abuse charges prompt NSW child protection review

children.content: (ABC News: Keana Naughton)
New South Wales Premier Chris Minns says his government is taking steps to look at any gaps in child protection regulations, after the shocking arrest of a childcare worker who allegedly
raped and abused 91 girls over a 15 year period.
The 45-year-old Gold Coast man is facing hundreds of charges over the abuse, which allegedly occured in Brisbane, Sydney and overseas between 2007 and 2022.
The allegations have raised questions about the strength and suitability of background checks for people working with children.
Minns has told parliament the situation is every parent's worst nightmare and he's determined to make sure there is better information sharing between jurisdictions.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australians on income support payments will receive $56 extra a fortnight from September, after federal government changes passed through parliament. The government committed to raising Jobseeker by $40 in May's federal budget, but that figure has increased to $56 due to indexation. As AAP reports, other changes which have been passed include: The age at which the higher rate of JobSeeker for single recipients is paid will be reduced from 60 to 55 for those who have been on payment for nine continuous months Commonwealth Rent Assistance maximum rates will increase by 15 per cent, with about 1.1 million households better off by, on average, $24 per fortnight About 57,000 single parents (90 per cent of whom are single mothers) with children aged eight and above will be eligible for the higher Parenting Payment (Single), adding at least $176.90 per fortnight to the support they receive until their youngest child turns 14
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Extra welfare supports have just passed parliament

children.content: Australians on income support payments will receive $56 extra a fortnight from September
, after federal government changes passed through parliament.
The government committed to raising Jobseeker by $40 in May's federal budget, but that figure has increased to $56 due to indexation.
As AAP reports, other changes which have been passed include:
The age at which the higher rate of JobSeeker for single recipients is paid will be reduced from 60 to 55 for those who have been on payment for nine continuous months
Commonwealth Rent Assistance maximum rates will increase by 15 per cent, with about 1.1 million households better off by, on average, $24 per fortnight

About 57,000 single parents (90 per cent of whom are single mothers) with children aged eight and above will be eligible for the higher Parenting Payment (Single), adding at least $176.90 per fortnight to the support they receive until their youngest child turns 14

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Supermarket giant Woolworths has been accused of under-paying former employees more than $1 milion in long-service leave. Wage Inspectorate Victoria has filed more than 1,000 charges against Woolworths Group, alleging it failed to pay 1,235 former Victorian employees between 2018 and 2021. Alleged underpayments ranged from $250 to more than $12,000. The matter will be heard in Melbourne Magistrates court in September and the ABC has contacted the organisation for comment. Reporting by Lexie Jeuniewic
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Woolworths accused of underpaying employees in long-service leave

props.alt: The Woolworths logo, with the words 'the fresh food people'

children.content: (ABC News)
Supermarket giant Woolworths has been
accused of under-paying former employees more than $1 milion
in long-service leave.
Wage Inspectorate Victoria has filed more than 1,000 charges against Woolworths Group,
alleging it failed to pay 1,235 former Victorian employees
between 2018 and 2021.
Alleged underpayments ranged from $250 to more than $12,000.
The matter will be heard in Melbourne Magistrates court in September and the ABC has contacted the organisation for comment.
Reporting by Lexie Jeuniewic

items.synopsis: The High Court of Australia ruled the land at Ponde was invalidly prescribed, and the pair were denied procedural fairness and should have been given notice of the declaration.

title.children: Hells Angels members win High Court of Australia battle with SA government

items.synopsis: A zoo in eastern China is denying suggestions one of its bears might be a staff member in a costume as images of the animal standing like a human circulate online.

image.altText: Woman holding two-year-old boy wearing a green jumper stands at a gate outside a house, smiling.

title.children: Welcome to the outback town where residents are renting to buy their homes

title.children: Bat population causing an 'increased risk of wildlife strikes' at Bendigo Hospital's helipad

image.altText: Man in black suit with black shirt

items.synopsis: Police and Safework NSW are investigating the death of Akshay Doultani, an 22-year-old international student who was killed while working as an Uber Eats delivery rider in Sydney's north-west two weeks ago.

image.altText: A close-up of a golden lion tamarin monkey looking at the camera.

items.synopsis: Once on the brink of extinction with only about 200 animals in the wild, the golden lion tamarin population has rebounded to around 4,800 individuals hopping between branches in the Brazilian rainforest.

title.children: 'We are celebrating': Vaccines help Brazil's golden monkeys rebound from near extinction

image.altText: black and white image of spotted western quoll

items.synopsis: The tiny, native western quoll that was all but wiped out in Western Australia has been reintroduced to parts of the state, and this time their welfare is being watched over by drones.

title.children: This native species disappeared 100 years ago, but ecologists are bringing them back from the brink

image.altText: Dianne Marcus standing outside her home

items.synopsis: Dianne wants to join the hordes of people installing solar panels on their roofs. But as long as the Victorian government's her landlord that's not likely to happen.

title.children: Dianne wants solar panels, but her landlord won't allow it. The twist? She lives in government housing

image.altText: Two loafs of gluten free sour dough

title.children: The cost of bread could get higher amid the cost of living crunch. Here's why

image.altText: A Portuguese striker, an American defender and goalkeeper go flying as the ball cannons off the post in a match.

items.synopsis: Defending champion the United States stays alive in the Women's World Cup by the width of a post, England's Lauren James destroys China's hopes, and a false fire alarm interrupts play in Auckland. These are the five talking points from last night.

title.children: Markets in red as US loses AAA credit rating over debt limit stand-offs, Australian dollar slumps

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A Woolworths spokesperson says the supermarket giant discovered the non payment of long service leave and reported it to Wage Inspectorate Victoria in 2022. "Since 2019, the group has undertaken an extensive end-to-end review of its payroll systems and processes." "As a result, discrete instances of potential non compliance in relation to long service leave were identified." "We self reported these matters to Wage Inspectorate Victoria in February 2022. " "We have since made back payments or corrected leave balances to affected team members, including interest and superannuation." "We have apologised to affected team members and strengthened our payroll systems to address the long service leave issues we identified." It's the latest wage scandal to engulf Woolworths after it admitted underpaying thousands of workers nearly $600 million, amid a string of underpayment scandals at major Australian companies. Under the Victorian Long Service Leave Act, employees are eligible for long service leave after seven years of continuous service with one employer.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Woolworths says long service leave backpaid

children.content: A Woolworths spokesperson says the supermarket giant discovered the non payment of long service leave and reported it to Wage Inspectorate Victoria in 2022.
"Since 2019, the group has undertaken an extensive end-to-end review of its payroll systems and processes."
"As a result, discrete instances of potential non compliance in relation to long service leave were identified."
"We self reported these matters to Wage Inspectorate Victoria in February 2022. "
"We have since made back payments or corrected leave balances to affected team members, including interest and superannuation."
"We have apologised to affected team members and strengthened our payroll systems to address the long service leave issues we identified."
It's the latest wage scandal to engulf Woolworths after it admitted underpaying thousands of workers nearly $600 million, amid a string of underpayment scandals at major Australian companies.
Under the Victorian Long Service Leave Act, employees are eligible for long service leave after seven years of continuous service with one employer.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Woolworths is facing more than 1,000 criminal charges in Victoria over allegations the firm failed to pay more than $1 million in long service leave to former employees. Wage Inspectorate Victoria alleges Woolworths and its subsidiary Woolstar underpaid 1,235 former employees their long service leave entitlements, with underpayments ranging from $250 to $12,000. The regulator alleges that Woolworths and Woolstar broke Victoria's Long Service Leave Act between 2018 and 2021. Failure to pay long service leave is a criminal offence in Victoria and attracts large fines. The case will begin in the Melbourne Magistrates' Court next month. Here's Robert Hortle, Victoria's Wage Inspectorate commissioner: "Victorians expect businesses with significant payroll resources to get this stuff right. "They’d be disappointed to see a household name facing underpayment allegations. "Long service leave is a long standing, valued workplace entitlement in Victoria, and the Wage Inspectorate is here to ensure it is paid when it is owed. "The amount of underpayment never tells the full story in long service leave matters." The Wage Inspectorate is also taking action against Optus, CommSec and Bank West alleging they broke the long service leave laws. In 2021, a Wage Inspectorate investigation found more than 4,000 former Coles workers in Victoria were underpaid almost $700,000 in long service leave entitlements.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Woolworths faces criminal charges over long service leave

children.content: Woolworths is facing more than 1,000 criminal charges in Victoria over allegations the firm failed to pay more than $1 million in long service leave to former employees.
Wage Inspectorate Victoria alleges Woolworths and its subsidiary Woolstar underpaid 1,235 former employees their long service leave entitlements, with underpayments ranging from $250 to $12,000.
The regulator alleges that Woolworths and Woolstar broke Victoria's Long Service Leave Act between 2018 and 2021.
Failure to pay long service leave is a criminal offence in Victoria and attracts large fines.
The case will begin in the Melbourne Magistrates' Court next month.
Here's Robert Hortle, Victoria's Wage Inspectorate commissioner:
"Victorians expect businesses with significant payroll resources to get this stuff right.
"They’d be disappointed to see a household name facing underpayment allegations.
"Long service leave is a long standing, valued workplace entitlement in Victoria, and the Wage Inspectorate is here to ensure it is paid when it is owed.
"The amount of underpayment never tells the full story in long service leave matters."
The Wage Inspectorate is also taking action against Optus, CommSec and Bank West alleging they broke the long service leave laws.
In 2021, a Wage Inspectorate investigation found more than 4,000 former Coles workers in Victoria were underpaid almost $700,000 in long service leave entitlements.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Asian markets are in the red as investors worry about the fallout from the US losing its top AAA credit rating from global agency Fitch. Shrinking manufacturing industries in China, the Eurozone and the US also weighed on sentiment. Manufacturing in the Eurozone contracted in July at the fastest pace since May 2020 because of dropping demand. The Australian market is down more 1 per cent in afternoon trade, and the Australian dollar has lost 0.5 per cent so far today, dropping below 66 US cents, after taking a tumble overnight. In Japan, the Nikkei 225 has fallen by 2 per cent as chip makers weigh on the benchmark index, tracking a fall on the Nasdaq. Investors are waiting for the reaction on Wall Street tonight after Fitch cut the US credit rating. Yields on US Treasury bonds fell on the news. The White House has slammed the move saying it "strongly disagrees with this decision". And US Treasury secretary Janet Yellen also took issue with Fitch's move. "I strongly disagree with Fitch Ratings' decision. "The change by Fitch Ratings announced today is arbitrary and based on outdated data. "President Biden and I are committed to fiscal sustainability. "The most recent debt limit legislation included over $1 trillion in deficit reduction and improved our fiscal trajectory. "Looking forward, President Biden has put forward a budget that would reduce the deficit by $2.6 trillion over the next decade through a balanced approach that would support investments for the long-term." Congress agreed to a deal in June which suspended the nation's US31.4 trillion borrowing limit until January 2025. But Steven Ricchiuto, US chief economist at Mizuho Securities, says the US needs to cut spending. "It's an unsustainable budget situation because the economy can't even grow its way out of this problem. "Therefore, they're going to have to either tackle it or accept the consequences of potential further additional downgrades." with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Markets hit by US credit rating downgrade

children.content: Asian markets are in the red as investors worry about the fallout from the US losing its top AAA credit rating from global agency Fitch.
Shrinking manufacturing industries in China, the Eurozone and the US also weighed on sentiment.
Manufacturing in the Eurozone contracted in July at the fastest pace since May 2020 because of dropping demand.
The Australian market is down more 1 per cent in afternoon trade, and the Australian dollar has lost 0.5 per cent so far today, dropping below 66 US cents, after taking a tumble overnight.
In Japan, the Nikkei 225 has fallen by 2 per cent as chip makers weigh on the benchmark index, tracking a fall on the Nasdaq.
Investors are waiting for the reaction on Wall Street tonight after Fitch cut the US credit rating.
Yields on US Treasury bonds fell on the news.
The White House has slammed the move saying it "strongly disagrees with this decision".
And US Treasury secretary Janet Yellen also took issue with Fitch's move.
"I strongly disagree with Fitch Ratings' decision.
"The change by Fitch Ratings announced today is arbitrary and based on outdated data.
"President Biden and I are committed to fiscal sustainability.
"The most recent debt limit legislation included over $1 trillion in deficit reduction and improved our fiscal trajectory.

"Looking forward, President Biden has put forward a budget that would reduce the deficit by $2.6 trillion over the next decade through a balanced approach that would support investments for the long-term."
Congress agreed to a deal in June which suspended the nation's US31.4 trillion borrowing limit until January 2025.
But
Steven Ricchiuto, US chief economist at Mizuho Securities, says the US needs to cut spending.
"It's an unsustainable budget situation because the economy can't even grow its way out of this problem.
"Therefore, they're going to have to either tackle it or accept the consequences of potential further additional downgrades."
with Reuters
